title: [ESLint] Propose rules: `prefer-useCallback`, `guard-memo`?!
body:
**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**
Features.

**What is the current behavior?**
No these rules.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem. Your bug will get fixed much faster if we can run your code and it doesn't have dependencies other than React. Paste the link to your JSFiddle (https://jsfiddle.net/Luktwrdm/) or CodeSandbox (https://codesandbox.io/s/new) example below:**
N/A

**What is the expected behavior?**
Give linting warning.

**Which versions of React, and which browser / OS are affected by this issue? Did this work in previous versions of React?**
\> 16.8

---

From my experiences with hooks so far, it seems that in any function component, `const` assignment would always associate with one hook for sure. (correct me if I were wrong...)

Anyway, I think we can have a new `prefer-useCallback` rule, which gives warning whenever `const fn = () => {...}` does not wrapped with `useCallback`.  Even it does not pass with `React.memo` component, the memorization punishment can still be paid back after couple re-rendering process, and it would always ready if we later found we need to wrap some of components with `React.memo`.

Also, it almost 100% wrong when such a function pass into a `React.memo` wrapped component, which may not be obvious. Maybe we can have a lint rule to catch up this too (`guard-memo`)? Does it possible?

PS. naming on rules is randomly running into my mind. Maybe someone have a better name in mind?
